title: Inductance - emf when current is alpha t-squared

content.description: An inductor in a circuit has an inductance <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> and the current <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"> <mi>I</mi> </math> in the inductor varies with time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> according to the equation <math alttext="I of t equals, alpha t squared" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>α</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, where <math alttext="alpha" overflow="scroll"><mi>α</mi></math> is a constant. The induced <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> of the inductor is zero at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
content.question: What is the magnitude of the induced <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"> <mi>emf</mi> </math> of the inductor as a function of time?

choices.label: <math alttext="one third L alpha t cubed" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>L</mi><mi>α</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></math>

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
